setup.secondary_label: Second entry long (after failed bar 23 breakout)

entry_quality.signal_bar_notes: Small bull bar (2.5 points) with close at high and no lower tail is acceptable structure, but EXTREMELY low volume (only 2 contracts vs 16-31 on prior bars) indicates exhaustion after 5 consecutive bull bars. This is a vacuum/climax signal, not strength.

risk_reward.stop_notes: Stop at 6908.50 was properly placed below the bull spike low (bar 32 at 6908.25), not just below signal bar. This protects the entire move. Risk of 5.75 points was reasonable.
risk_reward.target_notes: No target specified at entry. Reasonable targets would be: measured move to 6926 (2R), prior day close at 6934.50 (3.5R), or prior day high at 6941 (4.6R). Actual exit at 6931.25 was near the measured move/prior close area.

management.management_notes: Held for 2.96R profit and exited 3.25 points below prior day close magnet. This shows discipline to hold through pullbacks for a swing profit rather than scalping early.

what_was_good: Direction alignment: Entered long when Always-In was Long after 5 consecutive bull bars, trading with the clear momentum
Stop placement: Used the low of the bull spike (bar 32 at 6908.25) rather than just below signal bar, protecting the entire move
Profit-taking discipline: Held for 2.96R and exited near prior day close magnet at 6934.50 instead of scalping early
Second entry recognition: Correctly identified this as second attempt above tight trading range after bar 23 failed breakout
what_was_flawed: Signal bar misidentification: Claimed bar 36 was a bear bar when data shows it was bull (O=6916.25, C=6917.25), indicating rushed analysis without actually reading the bars
Extremely low volume ignored: Signal bar had only 2 contracts vs 16-31 on prior bars - a screaming exhaustion warning after 5 consecutive bull bars that should have stopped the trade
Buy climax entry: Entered after 5 consecutive bull bars that moved 11.75 points - this is late in the move where early bulls take profits and late bulls get trapped
Middle-of-range location: Entry at 6914 was in middle third of prior day's range and 20 points below prior close magnet with no clear path
coaching.better_alternative: Enter on bar 32 or 33 (first or second bull bar of the spike, not the fifth), or wait for a deeper pullback to 6908 area for better location, or skip entirely after seeing 5 consecutive bars with declining volume
coaching.keep_doing: Protect below the spike low - your stop at 6908.50 below bar 32 was correct Brooks technique, continue using the start of the move rather than just the signal bar
coaching.stop_doing: Entering after 5 consecutive trend bars with declining volume - this is a buy climax where early bulls exit and late bulls get trapped
rules_for_next_20_trades: Volume confirmation: Before entering after a spike, compare signal bar volume to prior 3-5 bars - if less than 50% of average, skip the trade as it signals exhaustion not continuation

Consecutive bar count filter: Do not enter long after more than 3 consecutive bull bars closing near highs - wait for pullback to moving average or spike start for first or second entry instead of fifth
Magnet distance assessment: Identify nearest major magnet before entry - if more than 15 points away with no clear momentum path, reduce position 50% or skip entirely

llm_response.grade_explanation: Trade made 2.96R with correct direction (Always-In Long) and proper stop placement below spike low. However, entry was late after 5 consecutive bull bars, signal bar had extremely low volume (exhaustion), trader misidentified bar 36 as bear when it was bull, and location was marginal in middle of range 20 points from magnet. Succeeded despite flaws because overall context was bullish and trader held for swing - a 'got lucky' trade that worked but violated Brooks principles about late entries and ignoring volume warnings.
llm_response.coaching_summary: You bought the fifth consecutive bull bar after an 11.75-point spike, ignoring the signal bar's extremely low volume (2 contracts vs 16-31 prior) - classic exhaustion. Brooks: 'Best trades are first and second entries, not the fifth push.' You also misidentified bar 36 as bear when actually bull, showing rushed analysis. Trade worked because you were with Always-In and held for 2.96R, but you got lucky. Next time: count consecutive bars and check volume - after more than 3 bars or volume below 50% average, wait for deeper pullback or skip.
